title: Luciano Chiarugi
text:
Luciano Chiarugi (; born 13 January 1947) is an Italian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager and former player who played as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a>.
Club career.
Born in <a href="Ponsacco">Ponsacco</a>, <a href="Province%20of%20Pisa">Province of Pisa</a>, Chiarugi started his career with <a href="ACF%20Fiorentina">Fiorentina</a>, being part of the lineup that won the <a href="1968%E2%80%9369%20Serie%20A">1968–69 Serie A</a> title. After seven seasons with the "viola", Chiarugi moved to <a href="A.C.%20Milan">A.C. Milan</a> in 1972, being instrumental to the "rossoneri" triumph in the <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20European%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">1972–73 European Cup Winners' Cup</a>, won thanks to a goal by him in the <a href="1973%20European%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup%20Final">final</a> match against <a href="Leeds%20United%20F.C.">Leeds United</a>, finishing the competition as top scorer.
In 1976, he was sold to <a href="S.S.C.%20Napoli">Napoli</a> in an exchange bid with <a href="Giorgio%20Braglia">Giorgio Braglia</a>, with whom he shared the same nickname: "Cavallo Pazzo" ("Crazy" or "Mad Horse", in Italian). He played two seasons with the "azzurri", winning a <a href="Coppa%20Italia">Coppa Italia</a> and an <a href="Anglo-Italian%20Cup">Anglo-Italian Cup</a>. He played for <a href="Serie%20B">Serie B</a> team <a href="U.C.%20Sampdoria">Sampdoria</a> in 1978–79, and then back to Serie A with <a href="Bologna%20F.C.%201909">Bologna</a> the following season. After spells with minor league teams <a href="Rimini%20Calcio%20F.C.">Rimini</a>, <a href="Rondinella%20Calcio">Rondinella</a> and <a href="U.S.%20Massese%201919">Massese</a>, Chiarugi retired from football in 1986.
International career.
Chiarugi also gained three caps for the <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy national football team</a>, making his debut on 22 November 1969 in a 3–0 win over <a href="East%20Germany%20national%20football%20team">East Germany</a>.
Style of play.
Known in Italian football for his impetuous nature, pace and technique, which gained him the nickname "Cavallo Pazzo" (Crazy Horse), Chiarugi was a quick, energetic, and highly creative <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a> with an eye for goal and excellent <a href="Dribbling%23Association%20football">dribbling</a> skills, known for his individualistic playing style, as well as his use of elaborate <a href="Dummy%20%28football%29">feints</a> and <a href="Nutmeg%20%28football%29">nutmegs</a> to beat opponents. He was also known for his accurate striking and <a href="Cross%20%28football%29">crossing</a> ability, and was effective from set-pieces; this allowed him to play both as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29%23Striker">striker</a>, or as a <a href="Midfielder%23Winger">winger</a> on either flank. However, despite his talent, he was also popularly considered as a <a href="Diving%20%28association%20football%29">diver</a>, causing the Italian media to create the <a href="Italian%20language">Italian</a> <a href="neologism">neologism</a> "chiarugismo", a synonym of "football diving", after his name.
Coaching career.
After his retirement as a player in 1986, Chiarugi joined the <a href="ACF%20Fiorentina">Fiorentina</a> youth team coaching staff. In his career, he served as Fiorentina's <a href="Caretaker%20manager">Caretaker manager</a> three times. Late into the <a href="1992%E2%80%9393%20Serie%20A">1992–93 season</a>, Chiarugi (jointly with <a href="Giancarlo%20Antognoni">Giancarlo Antognoni</a>) replaced <a href="Aldo%20Agroppi">Aldo Agroppi</a> with little fortune, as he did not manage to save them from relegation to Serie B after 54 consecutive seasons in the top flight. In <a href="Serie%20A%202000-01">February 2001</a>, following the dismissal of <a href="Fatih%20Terim">Fatih Terim</a>, Chiarugi was installed as caretaker coach for a single match, a 2–1 loss to <a href="A.S.%20Bari">Bari</a>, before the appointment of <a href="Roberto%20Mancini">Roberto Mancini</a>. Following the departure of <a href="Ottavio%20Bianchi">Ottavio Bianchi</a>, Chiarugi was appointed again as caretaker coach during the dramatic <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20Serie%20A">2001–02 season</a>, which ended with relegation to Serie B and the successive club cancellation due to financial troubles, which ultimately led to Fiorentina's bankruptcy.
On 14 November 2007, he was announced as the new head coach of Tuscan <a href="Serie%20C2">Serie C2</a> side <a href="U.S.%20Poggibonsi">Poggibonsi</a>. He was sacked in September 2008 due to poor results.
